item.title: TSA Says Travelers Can Keep Shoes on at Airport Security
item.description: US travelers no longer have to worry about removing their shoes to go through standard airport security checkpoints, a change that will likely speed up screening for airline passengers.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille, Myles Miller, Ellen M Gilmer

media:content.media:description: ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ROBYN BECK/AFP

item.title: Taiwan Holds Most Expansive Annual Drills Ever to Counter China
item.description: Taiwan is preparing to kick off its most expansive annual military drills ever — underscoring President Lai Ching-te’s drive to protect the self-run democracy from China’s assertiveness.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: An armored personnel carrier in Taoyuan, Taiwan, during the Han Kuang military drills in 2024.

item.title: Supreme Court Lets Trump Proceed With Broad Workforce Cuts
item.description: The US Supreme Court let President Donald Trump move ahead with plans to dramatically reduce the size of the federal government, lifting a court order that had blocked 19 federal departments and agencies from slashing their workforces.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross a street near the US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Trump Tariff ‘Blank Check’ Must Be Curbed, Appeals Court Told
item.description: A group of small businesses that won an order finding President Donald Trump’s sweeping global tariffs illegal urged a federal appeals court to uphold that decision and block the trade levies.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: A container ship at the Port of Los Angeles.

item.title: US Acts on Foreign Ownership of Farmland Amid China Tension
item.description: The Trump administration is tightening its grip on foreign ownership of farmland amid continuing concerns over Chinese investment in America’s heartland.
item.dc:creator: Ilena Peng

media:content.media:description: Agricultural land near Denver, Colorado, US, on Saturday, Aug. 19, 2023. Some $5 trillion of capital investment may be needed to deliver on aviation's goal of reaching carbon neutrality by 2050, almost all of it plowed into sustainable fuel production and renewable power generation, according to McKinsey & Co. Photographer: Bing Guan/Bloomberg

item.title: Job Market Cooling May Be an Early Omen for Midterms
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, economy editor Molly Smith looks at the details of the last jobs report and what it may mean for the midterm elections. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Molly Smith

item.title: US Sanctions Target North Korean Fake-Tech-Worker Scheme
item.description: The US slapped sanctions on individuals and companies linked to a scheme that involves recruiting North Koreans to pose as American tech workers and help fund Kim Jong Un’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle

media:content.media:description: A North Korean flag flies at the Embassy of North Korea compound in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Saturday, March 20, 2021. Kim Jong Un’s regime cut off diplomatic relations with Malaysia, accusing it of a “super-large hostile act” after its top court ruled a North Korean man can be extradited to the U.S. face money-laundering charges. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Finance Head Cautions Against Rushing New Inflation Goal
item.description: South Africa’s finance minister said work on lowering the inflation target is “progressing well” but cautioned against rushing the decision.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: South Africa's finance minister Enoch Godongwana

item.title: Ex-NYPD Chief Says Warning on Mayor’s Policies Led to Ouster
item.description: A former high-ranking New York City police official alleged in a lawsuit that he was forced out of his job for raising concerns about the actions of an anti-crime unit created by Mayor Eric Adams.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: A New York Police Department officer in New York.

item.title: Trump Says Powell Should ‘Resign Immediately’ If He Misled Congress
item.description: President Donald Trump said Jerome Powell should “resign immediately” if allegations from an administration official that the Federal Reserve chair misled lawmakers prove true, while deepening his personal attacks against the head of the central bank over interest rate policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks during a cabinet meeting in the Cabinet Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on July 8, 2025. (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS / AFP) (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Two Killed in Houthi Attack on Cargo Ship in Red Sea
item.description: A Houthi militant attack on a Liberian-flagged cargo ship in the Red Sea killed at least two crew members and left the vessel without propulsion in the latest sign that the Tehran-backed group is once again escalating its maritime assaults in the vital trade route.
item.dc:creator: Mohammed Hatem, Erik Olsson, Verity Ratcliffe, Catherine Cartier

media:content.media:description: The Magic Seas vessel.

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Hosts Modi in Bid to Turn India Into a Major Trade Partner
item.description: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva wants to deepen trade ties with India, the world’s most populous nation. The question as he hosts Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Brasilia on Tuesday is how to go about it.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, left, and Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister

item.title: Rubio Impostor Used AI, Signal to Contact Foreign Officials
item.description: Someone pretending to be Secretary of State Marco Rubio used AI-generated voice technology and a fake Signal account to contact foreign officials and at least one member of Congress, the latest case of impostors mimicking senior US officials.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Set 50% Copper Tariff, Wait Year on Drug Levies
item.description: President Donald Trump said he planned to implement a 50% duty on copper imports as part of a set of looming sectoral tariffs, while also indicating he could offer pharmaceutical manufacturers at least a year before applying a crippling 200% tariff on their foreign-made products.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: Worker handles copper plates in a copper electrolysis plant at the Zijinshan mine in Longyan, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump to Meet Netanyahu Again in Push for Gaza Ceasefire
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would meet again with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday to further efforts to secure a ceasefire in Gaza following new momentum after a US proposal to temporarily halt the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, top left, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, bottom center, during a dinner in the Blue Room of the White House in Washington on July 7. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Vows No Tariff Extension, Hardens Threats on Copper, Drugs
item.description: President Donald Trump vowed to push forward with his aggressive tariff regime in the coming days, stressing he would not offer additional extensions on country-specific levies set to now hit in early August while indicating he could announce substantial new rates on imports of copper and pharmaceuticals.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: South Africa to Model Budget Impact of US Proposed 30% Tariff
item.description: South Africa’s National Treasury is worried that the US’s proposed 30% tariff could hit tax revenues and is modeling the impact it may have on the nation’s budget.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: The financial district and port in Cape Town, South Africa, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Enoch Godongwana, South Africa's finance minister, and his National Treasury officials were sent back to the drawing board last month after his revenue and spending plan failed to get buy-in from parties. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Ken Griffin-Backed Florida Bill for Non-Competes Becomes Law
item.description: Florida enacted legislation allowing non-competes of up to four years, handing a victory to Citadel’s Ken Griffin, who pushed for the policy.
item.dc:creator: Anna J Kaiser, Michael Smith

media:content.media:description: Ken Griffin

item.title: UN Criticizes Lethal Force in Kenya That Killed 31 People
item.description: The United Nations denounced the use of lethal force in clashes between Kenyan police and protesters, which killed at least 31 people, saying those responsible must be held to account.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff

media:content.media:description: Police remove tires from barricades during clashes with protesters in Nairobi on July 7.

item.title: Milei Approval Rating Holds as Argentines Worry More About Jobs
item.description: President Javier Milei’s approval rating and positive image remained well above domestic peers in June even as Argentines became increasingly worried about the job market after unemployment rose earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Javier Milei speaks in National Harbor, Maryland, on Feb. 22. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says He’s Weighing Federal Takeover of Washington, DC
item.description: President Donald Trump said his administration is weighing whether to take control of the city of Washington, DC, to help combat crime, in a move that would represent a dramatic upheaval to the capital’s half-century of home rule.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: The United States Capitol in Washington DC. Photographer: Mohammad Reza Mousavi/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: EU Weighs €100 Billion Fund for Ukraine in Next Budget Proposal
item.description: The European Union is considering setting up a €100 billion ($117 billion) fund to support Ukraine as its war with Russia following Moscow’s full-scale invasion shows no signs of ending.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Soldiers prepare a cannon to fire from an artillery position in the Sumy region of Ukraine.

item.title: Trump Slams Putin Again as He Backs More Weapons for Ukraine
item.description: President Donald Trump reiterated his displeasure with Vladimir Putin over the war in Ukraine and confirmed he’s sending more defensive weapons to President Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s government, sweeping aside an earlier pause by the Pentagon.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Ryan Chua, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump attends a cabinet meeting at the White House in Washington, DC, on July 8.

item.title: Macron Pushes Starmer to Recognize Palestine on Visit to UK
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron urged the UK to recognize the state of Palestine in an address to the British parliament that emphasized the need for cooperation amid Middle East tensions and uncertainty over US support.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, left, and Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a wreath laying ceremony at the statue of former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in Parliament Square in London, UK, on Tuesday, July 8, 2025. Macron arrived in the UK on Tuesday morning for the first state visit by a French leader since 2008.

item.title: A Tomato Fight With Mexico Is Set to Boost US Prices Nearly 10%
item.description: Consumers may soon be paying more for fresh tomatoes as a decades-long deal with Mexico expires in less than a week, absent a last-minute deal or extension.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Peterson

media:content.media:description: A bucket of tomatoes during a harvest at a farm in Limon de Los Ramos, Mexico.

item.title: French Minister Feared Equity Trading Exodus to UK After Dividend Tax Rule Change
item.description: France’s finance minister said he feared a “mass exodus” of equity trading to London if he hadn’t provided clarity to banks about the application of new dividend tax rules.
item.dc:creator: Gaspard Sebag

media:content.media:description: France's finance minister Eric Lombard

item.title: EU to Protect Airbus in US Trade Deal as Ferrari Set to Lose Out
item.description: As the European Union nears a trade deal with the US, its negotiators are focusing on protecting key industries from massive tariffs set to hit the bloc’s exports as soon as Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Benedikt Kammel, Stefan Nicola

media:content.media:description: An aircraft assembled at an Airbus manufacturing plant.

item.title: Gambia Rejects New Constitution That Allows Barrow to Extend His Rule
item.description: Gambian lawmakers rejected a new draft constitution that imposed presidential term limits, but contained a loophole that would have allowed President Adama Barrow to run for re-election after his current five-year term ends in 2027.
item.dc:creator: Modou Joof

media:content.media:description: Adama Barrow

item.title: Solar Stocks Fall After Trump Orders Limit to Tax Credits
item.description: Shares of US solar companies fell after President Donald Trump called for new rules that would limit access to tax incentives for renewable energy projects that had already been pared back by a $3.4 trillion budget bill.
item.dc:creator: Mark Chediak

item.title: UK Officials Kept in Dark Over Issues Plaguing Economic Data
item.description: UK officials were kept in the dark over a crucial report detailing major cultural failings at the statistics body that contributed to the breakdown of official unemployment data.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: City workers in the financial district of London.
